author: postcapone
content:
If killing them did not means leaving two Ethereum's where users are forced to decide which they support based on their account balances, everyone would support your perspective here.

The penalty mechanism is a pressure point whereby your users can be baited into an divorce where they beg for custody from an abusive parent.

author: darius510
content: This mechanism was bound to eventually result in a situation like now where you're forced to choose between bad choices, since you took the option to just rely on the status quo off the table, even though it is typically the safest choice. Right now you're basically forced to choose between 1) handing the keys to the kingdom to institutions that you can only cross your fingers and hope they wont misbehave, and your only defense against it is basically a self-destruct mechanism (that will probably backfire anyway). 2) delaying the merge yet again, and having to deal with an angry rabble and miners for an indefinitely longer period. Without the bomb you'd have been able to take a more careful approach to a situation that absolutely demands it.

author: darius510
content: The lesser of two evils here is obviously #2, but if I'm reading the room correctly that doesn't seem to be the way things are going, or at least no one wants to be the flag bearer for it

author: postcapone
content: That call was jokes

author: darius510
content: Frankly it just boggles my mind that given the choice between the miners that got you this far and the financial institutions that are currently at dangerous levels of centralization and just showed you the hand they're going to play once they've given control, that you'd side with them over miners. Both PoS and PoW being censorship resistant are predicated on a majority of independent validators/miners, which you still have on the mining side but categorically do not have on the staking side (yet, at least.) You are crazy to charge into this based on a theory that PoS *should* be more decentralized when the reality in front of you is that it is not.

author: darius510
content: And furthermore they will be given a window of opportunity to enshrine and calcify that power. It's so reckless I just can not wrap my brain around it.

author: postcapone
content:
Proof of Stake User Activated Soft Fork introduces a dynamic that is simply non existent in PoW: Users make decisions based on their account balances. Thinking that UASF is a "powerful tool" that Ethereum has is a straight up lie (from the call that just ended).

UASF exists in every blockchain, and has been used plenty of times. In a Proof of Work User Activated Soft Fork funds exist in both chains and the market gets to decide which chain is worth what.

Proof of Stake User Activated Soft Fork means that users can be coerced into following a fork they do not agree with because they are poor on the other fork.

Proof of Stake cannot possibly make a chain more censorship resistant for this reason.

Proof of Stake being an upgrade is a lie.

Scalability is a lie if it means you are rejecting the primary purpose of the technology to begin with.

author: darius510
content: Is it even a UASF? What is being discussed sounds more like a UAHF.

author: postcapone
content: It would more accurately be called a hard fork, but these guys take their documentation very seriously and their documentation defines it as UASF

>Proof of Stake User Activated Soft Fork means that users can be coerced into following a fork they do not agree with because they are poor on the other fork.

>Proof of Stake cannot possibly make a chain more censorship resistant for this reason.

Hit the nail on the head. Exactly how this is going to play out if the centralised validators everyone is concerned about (lido, coinbase, Kraken etc) get slashed.

After the call it feels like core devs have decided to play chicken with the centralised validators and the US government and there's a very real risk of losing.

And yes, Circle picks the winner.

Ethereum developers can be as maxi as they want, they will be left trying to prove that they are worth more than the real money.

author: postcapone
content:
Unfortunately though it's not true to say that solo validators would be a direct solution here

You would still have validators being law abiding citizens, and they would still feel compelled to censor of a new policy dropped

And it would still take them months to exit the pool

The government would be able to basically delete their stake by proxy due to the exit que problem (which also does not have an analog in PoW)

Cancelling the merge now would be a disaster. Following through with it puts a clock on becoming WalmartChain.

author: 0xsadcat
content:
reality: if america actually got really serious about enforcing sanctions enforcement in blocks, it's completely over for PoW.
before the chinese ban, china could take over bitcoin. now america can. mining at any scale is trivial to deanonymize due to inevitable asics that are made in very few fabs, and mining at large scale even with gpus is trivial to notice due to physical resource consumption (asic farms suffer from both).
miners would be forced to register with penalties if they don't - and given how hiding is impossible, ~100% of american hashrate would.
given energy prices elsewhere, america looks likely to control majority of btc hashrate. same would happen to any other pow eventually. knowing total hashrate and hashrate of registered miners would allow the execution of a censorship attack against foreign non-compliant miners once america controls enough. the end.
any gpu pow fork would be trivially killed, because no ethereum mining means there's no big pool of gpu miners. the attacking entity knows first it's going to attack - so it can rent gpus to kill any such fork early.
any gpu-dominant pow is a temporary state due to not enough investments into asics, either because of too small rewards, or expected shift to PoS, so the relevant comparison is to bitcoin, which shows a much more mature and inevitable PoW phase.

under PoS, such law would mean a practical end of custodial staking, which would be actually good news.
under the threat of a fork, existing custodial staking pools could be forced to shut down.
at worst, there would be a fork to remove hostile entities.
american solo stakers could leave the country, stake illegally (which is much harder to detect, as it's just a node) or shut down. but no technical way exists to force foreign stakers to censor once compliant stakers lose their power, one way or the other.

this is a scenario of a full scale assault by the american government. we are far from that, but PoS is the only existing consensus system that has any theoretical potential at winning.
therefore, all pro-PoW arguments are invalid, even if (which I don't necessarily agree with) in the current fear-based instead of actual enforcement-based environment it may be easier for PoW miners to ignore sanctions.

author: postcapone

Proof of Stake creates a social layer bias that is based on account balances and divorced from philosophy.

It is not possible for PoS to achieve any sociological or philosophical goals for a network which is tasked with firing money printers.

Because users can't just follow punkChain, they are broke

author: postcapone
content:
Yes. There are loads of very reasonable arguments why creating all these interconnected systems of value was a serious risk for Ethereum.

Turing completeness in the L1 is a risk that is likely to continue to be very difficult to defend.

You cannot defend it with PoS.

author: postcapone
content:
Again, defending turing completeness in the L1 is going to be a very very hard fight (this point has been being made since genesis)

But we should defend it

And we cannot with PoS

author: treyzania
content: so what do you propose?

author: treyzania
content: ultimately?

author: postcapone
content:
It honestly may be true that global consensus with turing completeness in the L1 was a bad idea from the get

Nobody enjoys that conversation...it means the future has to wait. Nobody wants that.

We should want to defend Ethereum, and we should try very hard to do that.

We cannot defend it with PoS. The only hope here is to enable withdrawals and urge Lido/CB/Kraken customers to demand withdrawal immediately.

And even that is parlaying the issue into the future.

IMO, defending Ethereum in a PoS config is not actually possible, but since Ethereum is very determined to try, the answer is to enable withdrawals.

author: postcapone
content: Turing completeness in the L1 means you will defend everyone's ideas to the death.

It will take 2 months for the US Validators to exit

They will lose user funds

The users will demand cuck money

author: postcapone
content:
No, it's very simple and factual

If I spin up a contract in Ethereum, you are tasked with defending my contract

You don't know if my contract is a good idea or not. It could be a gigantic pile of value leaning on a centralized stable coin that can jeopardize the entire chain.
